description: Since February 3rd 2020, travellers who have been to COVID-19 affected countries in the last 30 days need to obtain medical clearance three days before entering Tonga. Additionally, travellers must have remained in a country not affected by COVID-19 for at least five days prior to attempting entry.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 29th, 2020, the Government of Tuvalu announced that "restrictions prohibiting entry to Tuvalu of anyone who has been in China within 30 days of arrival in Tuvalu. This restriction includes entry to seafarers from foreign vessels that have been in China or “a high-risk country” (understood to be countries where coronavirus is present) in the last 30 days."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
On April 9, 2020, Pacific Islands Forum Leaders under leadership of the Pacific Islands Forum Chair and Prime Minister of Tuvalu,Honourable Kausea Natano, have invoked the Biketawa Declaration, to collectively respond to the COVID-19 pandemic as a major crisis to The Blue Pacific – its peoples, wellbeing and economies.

The Biketawa Declaration recognises that in time of crises, all actions must be taken on the basis that all members of the Forum are part of the Pacific Islands extended family. 

This could include expediting medical assistance, expediting customs clearance of medical supplies, and facilitating diplomatic clearances for chartered flights and commercial shipping.
type_text: Forum foreign ministers, involving representatives and authorities from Australia, New Zealand, Fiji, Nauru, Vanuatu, Marshall Islands and Tuvalu, responded to a call from the World Health Organisation (WHO) and agreed to establish a “Pacific Humanitarian Pathway on Covid-19.” Regional agencies want donors to use the humanitarian pathway to assist island governments with medical supplies and equipment as they respond to the Covid-19 pandemic. A Ministerial Action Group (MAG) was formed by the pariticipant governments to ensure that medical supplies, technical assistance and essential equipment can be moved seamlessly through the region.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On June 8, 2020, Tuvalu government received $3 million dollars from the Government of Australia to fund support for small businesses, front line workers fighting the COVID-19 pandemic and direct financial support for all citizens of the country.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_text: The Tuvalu Government received $3 million dollars from Australia as part of the economic relief package to fund support for small businesses, front line workers fighting the pandemic and direct financial support for all citizens of Tuvalu in the country.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On Tuesday 30th June 2020, Tuvalu's Ministry of Justice, Communication and Foreign Affiairs signed a 5-year bandwidth capacity agreement on behalf of the Government of Tuvalu with Kacific Broadband Satellites International Limited. 

One of the aims of the agreement is providing improved communication for telemedicine and distance learning between the Central Government and the Outer islands as a key part of Tuvalu's response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_text: The Government of Tuvalu signed an Internet Connectivity Agreement with Kacific Broadband Satellites International Limited to provide improved communication for telemedicine and distance learning between the Central Government and the Outer islands as part of its response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)
